Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: The PEcAn Project: A Community Platform for Ecological Forecasting
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulations play an essential role in ecological research, the management of national forests and other public and private land resources, and projections of climate change impacts on ecosystem services at the local, state, national, and international level. However, at the moment, there are a number of barriers slowing the pace of model improvement and reducing their wider use. First, the software for using each model is unique and does not communicate well with other models. Second, because each model is unique, the tools to manage data going into models, analyze models, and visualize results are not shared. In this project PEcAn (Predictive Ecosystem Analyzer) is being developed to provide a common set of software tools for researchers and land managers to effectively work with multiple ecosystem models and data. Web technologies will be used to allow distant modeling teams to share information, work together, and better use public and private cloud and supercomputing resources. Other tools will be developed to identify model errors and combine new and existing applications into workflows to make ecological research more efficient, better forecast ecosystem services, and support evidence-based decision making. The PEcAn team will also develop training tools for new users and work with the scientific community to add more models to PEcAn. PEcAn will make ecological research more transparent, repeatable, and accountable.

PEcAn is an open-source ecoinformatics system designed for ecologists with a range of modeling backgrounds to be able to better and more easily parameterize, run, analyze, and assimilate data into ecosystem models at local and regional scales. This project will expand the PEcAn user community, incorporate more models, and develop tools that are more intuitive and accessible. Further, the project intends to transform tools for managing the flows of information into and out of ecosystem models into a resilient, scalable, and distributed peer-to-peer network for managing the flow of this information among modeling teams and with the broader community. To support a larger number of models, data processing workflows will be improved and tools will be developed for multi-model visualization and benchmarking. Applications that distribute analyses across the PEcAn network, cloud, and high-performance computing environments will be used to better understand model structural error using data mining approaches. Models will benchmarked over a range of environmental conditions, allowing model improvement to be tracked and users to select the best models for different applications in an informed manner. Finally, PEcAn tools will be combined into customizable workflows for real-time synthesis, forecasting, and decision support. By allowing modelers to focus on science rather than informatics, and allowing ecologists to easily compare their data to models, PEcAn will greatly accelerate the pace of model improvement and hypothesis testing. These activities are essential for improving ecosystem models and reducing uncertainty of the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and carbon cycle-climate feedbacks. Project information and results are available at http://pecanproject.org while project computer code is available at https://github.com/pecanproject.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Predictive Ecosystem Analyzer (PEcAn) is common set of open-source software tools developed by a team of researchers based at the Boston University, University of Illinois, Dept of Energy, and University of Wisconsin-Madison, among numerous other collaborating teams. The software tool allows ecologists to credibly use models to make informed decisions about the state and evolution of the biosphere, including its carbon and water exchanges. As an “ecoinformatics tool”, the intellectual merit of PEcAn is to remove barriers that slow the pace of model development, limit calibration of these models with real-world data, and slow the adoption of modeling workflows for ecological research, management of public and private land resources, and projections of impacts from global change.

In this project, researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison contributed several key advances to the open-source ecoinformatics systems. The core objectives of this second phase award were to build community among modelers and data providers in ecology, expand use of the distributed network model, enhance tools for multi model evaluation, synthesis, and prediction, and provide an accessible system for real-time synthesis, forecasting, and decision support. Contributions from Wisconsin in this area were accomplished through partial support of three graduate students and two undergraduates, leading to code development, several papers, and graduate theses and broader impacts of student training, community building, and public outreach.

In the arena of community building, the UW team participated in several PEcAn open houses at national conferences, a workshop with groups of ecosystem modelers interested in adopting their models into PEcAn, and taught aspects of data assimilation in several summer schools and courses. A number of data providers, particularly from the eddy covariance flux community, the NSF-supported National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), and the Earth observing satellite community, were engaged to enhance metadata, application programming interfaces for data access, and open-source data sharing policies that allow tools like PEcAn to work seamlessly across multiple data repositories.

During the project period, the distributed network and data model of PEcAn was hardened. The University of Wisconsin system, one of the original partners, continued to serve as a testbed for database syncing, web based interfaces. In addition to thesis research conducted by graduate students, undergraduate researchers at Wisconsin were able to complete several ecosystem model projects by running workflows within this system.

Wisconsin researchers contributed to several multi-model synthesis tools that are now part of PEcAn. These include a unique model-data emulator tool that allows for parameter data assimilation and model calibration to occur rapidly in complex, computationally expenses models. The University of Wisconsin team also led development of a climate project statistical point-based downscaling tool which allows for easy use of global climate model projection output to drive ecosystem models.

Together this work has enabled a number of scientific advances in ecology. One of these advances is work being done to accelerate ecological hypothesis testing through real-time forecasting. Wisconsin researchers automated data processing workflows to enable other PEcAn researchers to incorporate these data into a carbon dioxide flux forecasting testbed, that now provides nightly multi-day forecasts at a range of forest and agricultural sites.

Through these contributions and those of the entire core team, we successfully were able to expand the PEcAn user community, incorporate more models, and develop tools that are more intuitive and accessible. It is now feasible and growing more routing to conduct distribute analyses across the PEcAn network, cloud, and high-performance computing environments for ecological modeling, data assimilation, and benchmarking. By allowing modelers to focus on science rather than informatics, and allowing ecologists to easily compare their data to models, PEcAn accelerates the pace of model improvement and hypothesis testing. These activities are essential for improving ecosystem models and reducing uncertainty of the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and carbon cycle-climate feedbacks. Project information and results are available at http://pecanproject.org while project computer code is available at https://github.com/pecanproject
